title: Using text mining techniques to maintain translation memories

author: Andraž Repar, Department of Knowledge Technologies, Jožef Stefan Institute

segmentation: Hi so I'm in Russia Reaper and in addition to being a student here at the International Postgraduate School, also work for LLR, which is one of the largest translation companies in the region.
So a central piece of translation technology is something called a translation memory, which is essentially a database of translation.
Everything you translate, you store into a translation memory and then you can recall it and reuse it to later.

So for example, if I get a document to translate which is similar to something I've done in the past, I can use the translation memory to find segments that are already translated so I don't have to do everything from scratch.
Our our translation memory is essentially a sentence aligned parallel corpus.
What this means is you have a source sentence, for example, in English on one side of the corpus and its corresponding translation equivalent.
For example in Slovenia and on the other side of the corpus.
Or not, today most translation companies have lots of different translation memories and some of them are quite large, even over a million sentences or in some of the translation memories.
Or one of the problems with these memories is they are difficult to maintain.
For example, you cannot automatically group segments according to topics, which is something that would be very useful.
For example, machine translation or terminology extraction.
And.
This is exactly what we set out to do in our work.
We took one large translation memory that is used to store legal finance and marketing texts, and we created on topic ontology for it to see whether it contains any other topics.
In addition to this three.
And we didn't stop here.
We also.
You know we didn't only want to analyze existing databases.
We also wanted to classify new content.

Now the obvious route for for this would be tax classification, but for text classification you usually don't need a labeled data set, and constructing a labeled data set is costs money and takes time, which is not something most translation companies having abundance.

So instead of manual labeling, large set of segments with their topics, we use the ontology topics from the previous step as class labels in a text classification tasks task and we got some promising results.
And if you want more you can.
Talk to me outside at poster number 40 I think, yeah.
